title: Data quality assessment scenario
body:
This section brings together all that you have learnt throughout the data quality action plans course. We will imagine a fictional scenario in which you are responsible for a data set that has important, real-world uses. We will see how data quality action plans can be used to improve data quality management and impact on real people's lives.

    During this course, we have seen:

    • What makes a good data quality assessment
    • Why data quality action plans are a good way of managing data quality
    • How to design a data quality action plan
    • How to use a data quality action plan

    You can return to earlier modules if you would like to review any of this content.

title: About this course
body:
In government we need the right data so that we can provide services, make decisions and form policies.  Understanding the quality of the data we hold is the first step in using the data in the right way to provide the right services, make decisions and policies confidently.​

This course will cover the importance of good quality assessments, and a technique you can use to achieve it. The course is for anyone interested in learning more about carrying out regular assessments of data quality as part of managing data quality. ​It is not suitable for creating a one-off assessment of data for the purposes of analysis.

title: Why do we assess quality?
body:
Data quality assessments can be useful to all organisations that use data. Reflecting on your own situation is an important first step in exploring what can be learned from assessing data quality and understanding why it matters.

Because quality varies, we cannot simply say that data is “good” or “bad” quality. Data with quality problems can still be very useful because people can make allowances, or use parts of the data.

title: What is a data quality action plan?
Taking action on data quality
body:
You have decided to take action to measure and improve the quality of your data. When deciding what type of data quality assessment to use, you think about the fact that:

  • Your data set has multiple important purposes
  • Your data set has a lot of different fields
  • Different purposes depend on different fields
  • Some fields have more important data than others
  • You need to justify your approach and actions to non-data specialists

You therefore decide to take a data quality action plans approach to managing the quality of the data in your data set.

title: Summary
body:
There are many different ways to assess data quality. Over the rest of this course we will look at Data Quality Action Plans, but your organisation may choose a different approach.

However you choose to assess the quality of your data, make sure that any approach you use is:

  • Evidence based
  • Linked to purpose
  • Proactive
  • Communicated

title: The benefits of data quality action plans
Test your knowledge
body:
Consolidate what you have seen in this module with these short exercises.

At the start of this module, we looked at why data quality action plans are a good option for assessing and improving data quality. Below are some statements about data quality action plans. Are they true or false?

title: Step three - Measurements
body:
We have defined the purpose of the data, and identified the parts of the data that need to be correct in order to achieve that purpose.​

​Now we can use the data quality dimensions to define what correct would look like.

If you are not familiar with the data quality dimensions, now is a good time to go back to the Introduction to Data Quality Course and refresh your memory.​

title: Summary
body: In this module we have learned how to use a data quality action plan, how to find the root cause of quality problems and to take the right actions to improve quality.​

title: Summary
body:
Traditional data quality assessments often take a very thorough, bottom-up approach which can be effective in improving data quality, but they are often inefficient.

A data quality action plan focuses on your outcomes to give the most efficient and impactful improvements. Taking this top-down approach ensures that your most important outcomes are protected.

This module has looked at what data quality action plans are, and why they are an effective approach to data quality assessment. We also explored some of the benefits of using data quality action plans that are not part of more traditional approaches to assessing data quality. 

The next module looks at steps for designing a data quality action plan.
